<br/>

<b> Roland A. Knapp [^1] </b> (and many others over \~30 years)

### California's Sierra Nevada {style="color:#C1FFC1;"}

<hr color = #698B69>

-   One of the best protected mountain ranges.

-   40 million people within 1-day drive.

-   Introduced fish and diseases, water and air quality issues.

![](images/BlueCynPano.jpg){.absolute left="10mm"}

### A century of decline {style="color:#C1FFC1;"}

<hr color = #698B69>

<br/>

::: columns
::: {.column width="45%"}
-   Formerly abundant in montane habitats.

-   Absent from \> 90% of localities: fish, disease.

-   "Endangered" across species range.
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
![](images/Forester_Many%20RASI%20adults%20jumping_%20SD.JPG){.absolute right="0mm" width="55%"}
:::
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Fish arrive, frogs disappear {style="color:#C1FFC1;"}

<hr color = #698B69>

Overlapping habitat requirements, predation by trout on frogs.

### Amphibian chytrid fungus & chytridiomycosis {style="color:#C1FFC1;"}

<hr color = #698B69>

::: {style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
"Impact of chytridiomycosis on frogs is the most spectacular loss of vertebrate biodiversity in recorded history." (Skerratt et al. 2007)
:::

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="65%"}
-   <em> Batrachochytrium dendrobatids </em> (Bd).

-   From Asia, spread via commerce.

-   Montane amphibians are most susceptible.
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
![](images/bdlifecycle.jpg){.absolute right="0mm" width="37%"}
:::
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Extinction or beginning of recovery? {style="color:#C1FFC1;"}

<hr color = #698B69>

::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
<br/>

-   Most frog populations are extirpated after Bd arrival.

-   Some persist despite ongoing Bd infection.

-   Decades-long decline is reversing.
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
![](images/rasi_tadpoles_70459_jul2021.jpg){.absolute right="0mm" width="37%"}
:::
:::
